title: Integral Theory
description: An exploration of Ken Wilber's Integral Theory, its core models (AQAL), developmental stages, states, types, and applications for a holistic understanding.

paragraphs.summary: An overview of Integral Theory as a comprehensive meta-framework developed by Ken Wilber, aiming to integrate insights from diverse fields of knowledge and experience.
Introduction to the AQAL (All Quadrants, All Levels, All Lines, All States, All Types) model as the core organizing map of Integral Theory.
The four irreducible perspectives on any occasion: Interior-Individual (I), Exterior-Individual (It), Interior-Collective (We), and Exterior-Collective (Its).
The Interior-Individual quadrant, representing subjective consciousness, self-awareness, personal experience, thoughts, and feelings (the 'I' domain).
The Exterior-Individual quadrant, representing objective behavior, material body, neurophysiology, and observable actions (the 'It' domain of an individual).
The Interior-Collective quadrant, representing shared cultural values, worldviews, intersubjective meanings, and collective identity (the 'We' domain).
The Exterior-Collective quadrant, representing social systems, institutions, environments, economic structures, and material conditions (the 'Its' domain of a collective).
Hierarchical stages or levels of development representing increasing complexity, consciousness, and capacity, present in all quadrants (e.g., Spiral Dynamics, ego development).
Entities that are simultaneously wholes in themselves and parts of larger wholes, forming nested hierarchies (holarchies) of increasing complexity.
A hierarchical arrangement of holons where each level transcends and includes its predecessors, adding new emergent properties.
Various distinct capacities or intelligences that develop through levels, such as cognitive, emotional, interpersonal, moral, and spiritual lines.
Temporary, non-permanent states of consciousness, such as waking, dreaming, deep sleep, and various meditative or peak experiences (e.g., gross, subtle, causal, nondual).
Horizontal typologies or styles that can be expressed at any developmental level or state, such as gender types (masculine/feminine) or personality types (e.g., Enneagram, Myers-Briggs).
The error of confusing pre-rational or pre-conventional states with trans-rational or trans-conventional states because both are non-rational or non-conventional.
A model depicting consciousness as a spectrum of evolving structures or levels, from archaic to transpersonal, each with its own worldview and sense of self.
A model of human psychosocial development (based on Clare Graves' work) depicting evolving value systems or 'vMemes' (e.g., Beige, Purple, Red, Blue, Orange, Green, Yellow, Turquoise).
Theories (e.g., Jane Loevinger, Susanne Cook-Greuter) describing stages of increasing complexity in self-identity, impulse control, and interpersonal style.

Theories (e.g., Lawrence Kohlberg, Carol Gilligan) outlining stages of moral reasoning, from preconventional (self-interest) to conventional (societal norms) to postconventional (universal principles).
A developmental line referring to the capacity to engage with questions of ultimate meaning, purpose, transcendence, and the sacred.
The ordinary waking state of consciousness, primarily identified with the physical body and sensory experience.
States of consciousness associated with dreaming, visions, archetypal imagery, subtle energies, and deeper emotional experiences.
A state of profound formless awareness, often associated with deep dreamless sleep or deep meditation; the unmanifest source.
States of consciousness characterized by the realization of ultimate unity, where the distinction between subject and object, or self and other, dissolves (e.g., Turiya, Turiyatita).
The process of spiritual development focused on attaining and stabilizing higher states of consciousness, moving towards enlightenment or nondual awareness.
The process of psychological and structural development through successive stages or levels of consciousness, increasing complexity and capacity in various lines.
The process of addressing and integrating unresolved psychological issues, traumas, and 'shadow' aspects of the self, often through psychotherapy.
The process of applying one's developmental attainments (states, stages, types) to engage skillfully, compassionately, and effectively in the world.
An approach that honors and incorporates the valid insights from multiple methodologies and perspectives (e.g., first-person, second-person, third-person inquiries).
A customizable framework for personal development that incorporates practices across multiple modules (e.g., body, mind, spirit, shadow) to foster integral growth.
The process of bringing unconscious, disowned, or repressed aspects of the psyche into conscious awareness for integration and healing.
An approach to psychology that incorporates insights from various schools of thought within an AQAL framework, addressing all quadrants and levels of development.
A form of spirituality that aims to integrate all aspects of human experience—body, mind, soul, and spirit—within a developmental and quadrant-aware context.
Applying integral principles to political theory and practice, seeking to understand and integrate diverse perspectives and developmental levels in governance.
Approaches to business and organizational development that incorporate integral principles, focusing on purpose, people, planet, and profit with a developmental awareness.
An approach to environmentalism that considers all quadrants and levels, integrating scientific, cultural, individual, and systemic perspectives on ecological issues.
A holistic approach to health and healing that integrates conventional and complementary therapies, addressing all quadrants of a patient's being.
Educational philosophies and practices that aim to develop the whole person by addressing multiple lines of intelligence, stages of development, and states of consciousness.
A core tenet of Integral Theory viewing evolution (cosmic, biological, cultural, individual) as a fundamental drive towards increasing complexity, consciousness, and integration.
A key principle of development where each higher stage or level incorporates the essential capacities of earlier stages while adding new, more complex abilities.
The integral maxim that 'everybody is right' from their own limited perspective; each viewpoint holds a partial truth that needs to be included in a larger synthesis.
The four fundamental drives of Eros (the drive towards self-preservation, self-adaptation, self-transcendence, and self-dissolution/communion) operating in all holons.
The capacity to understand and adopt different perspectives (1st, 2nd, 3rd person, etc.), crucial for integral awareness and navigating complexity.
The understanding that one's developmental level (altitude) significantly shapes one's worldview, values, and how reality is perceived and interpreted.
Wilber's approach to spirituality that seeks to ground it in first-person experience and verifiable injunctions, rather than untestable metaphysical beliefs.
A state of pure, detached awareness that observes thoughts, feelings, and sensations without identification; a gateway to transpersonal states.
A key concept in Mahayana Buddhism, often integrated into Integral Theory, referring to the ultimate nature of reality as devoid of inherent, independent existence.
Complementary to Emptiness, this refers to the vibrant, luminous, and full presence of Reality in all its manifestations.
The realization of the ultimate inseparability of subject and object, spirit and matter, emptiness and form; the unitive ground of being.
The capacity to hold and integrate multiple perspectives simultaneously, leading to a more comprehensive and compassionate understanding of reality.
In Spiral Dynamics, a level of consciousness (Yellow, Turquoise) that can appreciate, integrate, and work with the values and perspectives of all preceding developmental stages.
An awareness of common criticisms leveled against Integral Theory (e.g., over-complexity, hierarchical nature, Wilber's interpretations) and integral responses.
Exploring how the AQAL model and integral principles can be practically applied to personal development, relationships, professional work, and societal issues.
